## This room will be closed and archived.
** @/all Please move discussion of this topic to our forum, or to one of the official Free Code Camp chat rooms: http://forum.freecodecamp.com/t/free-code-camp-official-chat-rooms/19390**

-----

hello

##Please note that we now recommend campers use their Campsite’s Facebook group for chatting instead of their campsite’s Gitter chatroom. 
We are doing this because few of our Campsite Gitter chatroooms have active synchronous discussions, and about 1/3rd of conversations consist of someone saying “hello” and not getting a response. Most of the discussions are asynchronous, which Facebook posts and group messages are better suited for.
We’ve removed this Gitter room from our Campsite directory. Still, we will keep it open for archival purposes, and you can keep using it if you’d like.
Here’s a short blog post about how our Campsites are evolving and growing: http://blog.freecodecamp.com/2015/09/jump-start-your-local-campsite-with-coffee-and-code.html

Yeah so I have to 'if' the function.
so through in a nice if/else and you’ve got it
if the string length ISN’T greater than num, you want to return the entire thing
but also remember: you only truncate if the string.length is greater than num
That is way more simple...lmao!
right.
if I am reading you right... I think
that would be return str.slice (0, num-3) + "...";
8 characters total. when you add ‘…’ it adds to the string
ok, lost me one sec
sorry 'hello wo...'
as do spaces
dots count as characters
so five letters, 3 dots
8 INCLUDING the ...
Would be 'hello w...'
can you think of how to do that with slice?
so my desired return is 'hello...'
so str = 'hello world' and num = 8
so ‘hello world’ has 11 characters, but i want it to have 8, INCLUDING a '...'
or in this case ‘hel'
str.slice(0,3) would return 0,1, and 2
so say i have a str = ‘hello world'
okay think of it this way: slice() will return from the first number, up to but not including the last number
knew it was work, but it is a habit...lol
roughly, it would slice the string at the position desired. when i attempted to use i failed, i could not figure out how to distinguish find the end of a word at the proper point.
which you could do, but it’s way extra work than you really need. do you know what slice() does?

split string into an array
get word count  and length of words
take the truncation number  and compare it to the length of words
and use that to truncate array
then rejoin array into a string and add "..."
here was my thought process...lol
although a tip: for the truncate a string bonfire you’re passed a string, not an array. you shouldn’t necessarily need a loop
that’s the fun of programming. let me know if you need any help
there is always more than one way to skin a........ well, anything with skin really...
@hessproject , ok i need to rethink my solution....
short answer: for in should be used to go over object properties, for each should be used for arrays
